text:
That Mustang GT is getting really tempting.  

The downside from a daily-driver perspective is that it's just a 2-door, which makes it less attractive for office lunch trips, but the performance is nice, and it's not so low to the ground that you're going to be constantly scraping up the bottom getting into and out of urban parking garages.  

Fuel economy isn't necessarily a primary consideration, but it's nice that it's "good enough" to not be a problem area either.  The magnetic suspension should make it more comfortable for everyday driving, and the ability to quiet the engine when you are coming home late and don't want to aggravate the neighbors is also a plus.  They've also iteratively given it a more modern look, so it doesn't seem like it's trying to be a pseudo-retro car anymore, which I wasn't really a fan of.

Overall, pretty nice.

text: Hydrogen is rather problematic for this kind of use.  One problem is that it will slowly leak from any tank you put it in, because the molecules are so small.  So you can't leave a (fuelled) vehicle doing nothing. for several days.  Another problem is that to get enough hydrogen into a manageably small volume you have to use extremely high pressure, and that brings serious safety concerns.  And if you do have a bad leak, hydrogen forms an explosive mixture with air over a very wide range of concentrations.   And to add to the fun, hydrogen burns with an invisible flame, so you could walk right into a fire because you couldn't see that it was there.
